awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: Distributed DNA Computations Operating on a Collection of Cell Membranes
awd_abstract_narration:
The biological cell membrane is an interface to communicate with other cells and its environment. This project seeks to enable DNA-based molecular-scale devices to operate on the membrane of cells and to provide for communications between these devices on distinct cells. The project has transformative potential for nanoscale applications in cell biology and medicine, including molecular-scale diagnostics and therapeutics. The ability to communicate between cells enhances the range of applications. Educational outcomes of the project will include course development, cross-disciplinary training and carefully supervised mentoring of students. 

This project is developing novel molecular-scale distributed computational architectures consisting of DNA digital circuits that operate on the membrane surfaces of a collection of cells. Each logical gate of each circuit is a DNA hairpin nanostructure tethered to a membrane protein on a cell surface. The DNA circuits take inputs and outputs (e.g., from or to molecules within or on the cell, the solution buffer medium, or DNA from DNA circuits of other cells) and perform computation tasks via DNA strand-displacement reactions. Moreover the outputs diffuse in solution to other cells, providing for communication between the DNA circuits of distinct cells. The project tasks include design, simulations and experimental demonstrations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
This project’s goal was to design, simulate and experimentally demonstrate novel molecular-scale distributed computational architectures. Digital DNA circuit computations were simultaneously executed on membrane surfaces of distinct cells, with communication between these cell-surface computations. Each logical gate of each circuit was a DNA nanostructure tethered (via aptamers and/or antibodies) to a membrane protein on a cell surface. The DNA circuits take inputs and outputs (e.g., from or to molecules within or on the cell, the solution buffer medium, or DNA circuits of other cells) and perform computation tasks via DNA strand-displacement reactions.

Recent impressive advances led to DNA-based nano-devices capable of molecular-scale computation, but mostly in synthetic environments, significantly limiting biological and medical applications. This project addresses an emerging challenge for DNA-based molecular-scale devices: to allow  operation in the immediate vicinity of cells and to provide for communications between these devices on distinct cells. This project presents novel distributed computational architectures consisting of DNA digital circuits that operate on the membrane surfaces of a collection of cells. One or more DNA circuits were attached to each cell. Each gate of a DNA circuit executes a logical operation implemented by DNA hairpins localized on the cell membrane by receptor-aptamer binding. Each of our DNA hairpin gates have an extended DNA strand that was an aptamer that binds to a particular cell membrane protein, providing attachment of our DNA hairpin gates to proteins of the cell membrane. Mobility of cell’s membrane proteins allows for proximity and communication between gates. The inputs of circuits are nucleic acid strands or other molecules on cell surfaces or in local solution, including molecules from other cell surfaces. The outputs of the circuits potentially include photonic signals, nucleic acid strands or other types of molecules. Moreover, the outputs were allowed diffuse in solution to other cells, providing for communication between the DNA circuits of distinct cells. The project work was distinct from previous demonstrated architectures for DNA circuits operating outside (apart from) or inside the cells, where circuits by our architectures operate on cell surfaces, and it leveraged the PI’s group prior work on localized hairpin cascade reactions on DNA nanotracks and also leveraged the PI’s group prior work on localized hairpin cascade reactions on DNA origami.

 

The project developed and investigated applications of DNA circuits that are localized upon cell surface membranes via membrane protein-binding aptamers.

 

Our group experimentally demonstrated a cascading hybridization chain reaction circuit using DNA hairpins to label and identify cancer cell lines (CCRF-CEM, Ramos, k562, HeLa). The results suggest the potential of interfacing the biocompatible, computational power of DNA circuits with diagnostic and therapeutic biotechnologies. A modular architecture was constructed that generalized the operation of 2- and 3-input circuits to any known set of available membrane proteins observed on a cell. Addressable DNA domains were extended from aptamers that identified specific membrane proteins. These addressable domains each hybridized specifically designated DNA hairpin nodes, and each node communicated the presence of the aptamer-bound membrane protein as an input at its specific index in the cascade circuit. Completion of the circuit by a positive observation of each input at each index of the cascade activated a fluorescent reporter complex, thus identifying the targeted cell type.

Two further distinct architectures were developed in this project; one non-catalytic and the other catalytic. The project’s work included design, simulation and experimental demonstration of several DNA circuits of these architectures, as well as prototype experimental demonstrations of several applications.

To improve the efficiency and output intensity of an identification circuit, the project developed an architecture for catalytic operation, which ensures that membrane proteins appearing at low frequency are not rate-limiting components to the operation of the circuit. A DNA hairpin node was be designed with oligonucleotides anchored onto membrane proteins serve as inputs to catalyze a forward reaction in the cascading hybridization chain reaction circuit. As catalysts, those inputs are released after initiating a reaction and can diffuse across the cell membrane to catalyze additional reactions. A higher ratio of circuit nodes to input nodes were used to significantly increase the amount of reporter complex activated by the circuit, producing an amplified output signal intensity.

 

We also developed architectures enabling targeting multiple cell lines in parallel and simultaneous operation of distinct DNA circuits. Distinct cell lines may frequently have overlapping membrane proteins causing errors inDNA circuit nodes. Provided that the first node of the cascade circuit was correctly assigned on the cell membrane surface, a barcoded domain instructs an ejector node to remove circuit nodes with non-matching barcodes to unify circuits on their respective cells. A parallel labelling strategy increased specificity of high-throughput cell sorting.

 

The cell surface membrane is an interface to communicate with cells, and therefore our experimental demonstrations of DNA circuits operating on cell surfaces will be very useful in medicine and cell biology applications.

 


Last Modified: 12/03/2022
Modified by: John H Reif
